title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: After twelve o'clock we set off again, and, toour astonishment, Lord Glenlyon insisted uponriding on with us to Dundee, which is 50 milesfrom Blair! Captain J. Murray also rode withus from Dunkeld.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: I should never haverecognized the grounds oi Dunkeld, so different didthey look without the encampment.f Beautifulas Dunkeld is, it does not approach the beautyand wildness of Blair.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We reachedDunkeld at half past eleven.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: Shortly after leaving Dunkeld, which is 20 mUesfrom Blair, and 15 from Cwpar Angus, we metLord Glenlyon in a carriage ; he jumped out, androde with us the whole way to Blair — and a mostbeautiful road it is.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: We got out at an inn (which was smaU, but veryclean) at Dunkeld, and stopped to let Vicky havesome broth.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: The peeps oi Dunkeld, with the River Tay deepin the bottom, and the view of the bridge and cathedral, surrounded by the high wooded hills, asyou approached it, were lovely in the extreme.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: I hear that at Dunkeld there werenearly 900 Highlanders, 500 being Athole men ;and, altogether, with the various Highlanders whowere on guard, tBere were 1000 men.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria
snippet: 37The two highest hills of the range on each sideare (to the left, as you go on after leaving Dunkeld') Craig-y-Bams and (to the right, immediately above Dunkeld) Craigvinean.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: I went into Edinburgh one day to see my old friendCharles Chambers ; he is now married, and lives in a handsome house in Drumsheugh Gardens ; his country house isat Dunkeld.

title: The works of Robert Burns;
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: I went through the heart of the Highlands by Crieff, Taymouth, the famous seat of lord Breadalbane, down the Tay, among cascades and druidical circles  of stones, to Dunkeld, a seat of the duke of Athole ; thence cross Tay and up one of his tributary  streams to Elair of Athole, another of the duke's seats, where I had the honour of spending nearly two days with his grace and family ; thence many miles through a wild country, among cliffs grey with eternal snows and gloomy, savage glens, until 1 crossed Spey and went down the stream tlirough Strathspey, so famous in Scottish music ; Badenoch, &c. until I reached Grant castle, where I spent half a day with sir James Grant and family  ; and then crossed the country for Sort George, but called by the way at Cawdor, the ancient seat of Macbeth ; there I saw the identical bed, in which tradition says king Duncan was murdered : lastly from Sort George to Inverness.

title: The complete poetical and prose works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: among cascades and Druidical circles of stones, to Dunkeld, a seat of the Duke of Athole ; thence across Tay, and up one of his tributary streams to Blair of Athole, another of the Duke's seats, where I had the honour of spending nearly two days with his grace and family ; thence many miles through a wild country among cliffs, grey with eternal snows and gloomy savage glens, till I crossed Spey and went down the stream through Strathspey, — so famous in Scottish music (41), — Badenoch, &c. till I reached Grant Castle, where I spent half a day with Sir James Grant and family ; and then crossed the country for Sort George, but called by the way at Cawdor, the ancient seat of Macbeth; there I saw the identical bed in which tradition says king Duncan was murdered; lastly, from Sort George to Inverness.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: After passing Lord Glenlyon's residence,and the assembled party, which I have thusalluded to, wTe were conducted by a broadgreen walk—resembling those of which thereis such an extent in the pleasure-groundsat Dunkeld — to the borders of the riverwhich flows through the domain.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: The drive from Dunkeld to Blair Athollies in the midst of very fine scenery.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: The view of this Cathedral, of Lord Glenlyon's garden and residence, of the Dunkeldwoods, and of the mountains in the background, as obtained from the end ofthe bridge,is of the most beautiful description.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: " Traist friendis, after maist harty commendacion, we pray you faill not to pass incontinent to the Kyrk of Dunkeld, and tak dounthe haill images thereof, and bring furth tothe Kyrk-zayrd, and burn them openly, andsiclyk cast doun the altaris, and purge the Kyrkof all kynd of monuments of idolatrye ; andthis ze faill not to do, as ze will do us singularempleseur * and so committis you to theprotection of God.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: visited this morning the cathedral of Dunkeld, part of which forms a beautiful ruin,roofed only by the sky, though otherwisenot much dilapidated, and part a church ofthe Presbyterian establishment.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: I also liked very much ourfriendly and chatty landlord; and certainly,with the attractions of the country, and ourpleasant reception, I could not help at leasta partial echo to the kind wish expressed onparting, that we should remain a month atDunkeld instead of a single day.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: We could neither find lodgings at the pleasantly situated inn at Birnam, just outsideDunkeld, nor at the Athol Arms, near thebridge.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol

snippet: As w-e approached Dunkeld, the mountainsrose before us in wilder and grander formsthan any we had yet seen in this line otcountry.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: In a map, which I have with me, I see thatthis division line is marked as commencing atNairn, on the Moray Firth, whence it crossesScotland diagonally from the above-mentionedpoint, not far from Inverness, first stretchingeastward for a short distance ; then descendingdue south to Alyth, and then bending in asouth-western direction by Blairgowrie, Dunkeld, Crieff, Doune, and Drymen, to Dunbarton on the Clyde, where it terminates.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol

author: Scott, Walter
snippet: At the skirmish of Dunkeld, 1689,he was shot dead by a Cameronian with a silverbutton (being supposed to have proof from the EvilOne against lead and steel), and his grave is stillcalled the " Wicked Laird's Lair."

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: When Glasgow was erected into an archbishopric, Dunkeld,Dunblane, and Galloway were put under that See, and thebishops of Dunblane became suffragan bishops under Glasgow.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: The successor to Bishop Cameron was William Turnbull,who was translated from Dunkeld to Glasgow in 1447, andconsecrated in 1448.
